text:
Hi, I’m John Lee Hancock,
director of “The Highwaymen.”

In this scene, Frank
Hamer, as played

by Kevin Costner,
and Maney Gault,

as played by Woody
Harrelson, have

come upon the body of
Wade McNabb, a convict

that these two guys had
paroled in an effort

to follow him and
track Bonnie and Clyde.

They found him at his aunt’s
house shot and beaten badly

with a baseball bat
and dead, and they’re

wondering how complicit
they are in this.

This was a Friday night,
and it was very late.

And we were all very tired
from a long week of work.

And it’s hard when
you’re creating rain,
and it’s cold already.

And so in some ways, that
inured to our benefit

because this is the low
point for Frank and Maney,
and they are tired.

“I never particularly liked
the weight of the deciding

who gets to live
and who doesn’t.”

If the two of these men
together make up one person,
Maney is the conscience.

And he wears his
heart on his sleeve.

And ultimately, I
think that the movie’s

kind of about the toll it
takes on these men’s soul
to have a very terrible gift.

They know how this
is going to end,
and it’s going to be violent.
And there will be no cheers.
“It’s never easy.
It’s never pretty.

There’s always blood
at the end of the road.
You know that.”

Kevin is very much
like Hamer in some ways

in that, in this scene, Hamer
is talking about the fame

that Bonnie and Clyde
have accumulated
and how it galls him.

And I think in
some ways, Kevin

himself is galled by the cult
of celebrity, if you will.

And in today’s world,
Bonnie and Clyde

would have many, many
Instagram followers.

This was one of the last
shots, next to last shot,

and I remember we were
all kind of sickly.

And I promised Woody
that he would only

have to walk one
time to the car,

so we timed it
out carefully so
that he only had to go once.

And we were at the
end of a long day.

And instead of shooting
this traditionally,

we got in the backseat,
and I just kind of liked

to see the silhouettes and
the sides of their faces

and for us to kind of imagine
what’s on their faces.
“I had to come.

Though I don’t
exactly know why.”
[music]
